# D Limiting differential equation for the double Stieltjes transform
## D. 1 Deriving the differential equation

For readability, we drop the time superscripts on the eigenvalues. By applying Itô's formula to $S^{(N)}$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
d S^{(N)}(z, \bar{z}, t)= & \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{d\left(\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}\right)}{\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)}+\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)} d \mu_{i} \\
& +\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)^{2}} d \lambda_{j}+\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)^{3}}\left(d \mu_{i}\right)^{2} \\
& +\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)^{3}\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)}\left(d \lambda_{j}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{d\left(\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}\right) d \mu_{i}}{\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}} \\
& +\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{d\left(\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}\right) d \lambda_{j}}{\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)^{2}\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)}+\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)^{2}\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}} d \mu_{i} d \lambda_{j}
\end{aligned}
$$

We need to specify certain terms:

- $\left(d \mu_{i}\right)^{2}=\left(d \lambda_{j}\right)^{2}=\frac{2}{N} d t$
- $d\left(\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}\right) d \mu_{i}=\frac{2 \sqrt{2}}{N} d \tilde{B}_{i} \sum_{\substack{k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{d W_{i k}}{\lambda_{j}-\lambda_{k}}\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle i \mid j\rangle=\frac{4}{N} \sum_{\substack{k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle^{2}\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\lambda_{j}-\lambda_{k}} d t$, where we first used the independence between $\tilde{B}$ and $\tilde{W}$, and then (A.4).
- $d\left(\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}\right) d \lambda_{j}=\frac{2 \sqrt{2}}{N} d B_{j} \sum_{\substack{l=1 \\ l \neq i}}^{n} \frac{d \tilde{V}_{i l}}{\mu_{i}-\mu_{l}}\langle l \mid j\rangle\langle i \mid j\rangle=\frac{4}{N} \sum_{\substack{l=1 \\ l \neq i}}^{n} \frac{\langle l \mid j\rangle^{2}\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\mu_{i}-\mu_{l}} d t$, where we first used the independence between $B$ and $W$, and then (A.4).
- $d \mu_{i} d \lambda_{j}=\frac{2}{N}\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2} d t$, (see Appendix A).

Thus, our Itô formula can be rewritten term by term as

$$
\begin{aligned}
d S^{(N)}= & \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{d\left(\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}\right)}{\left(\tilde{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)}+\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\tilde{z}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)} d \mu_{i} \\
& +\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\tilde{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)^{2}} d \lambda_{j}+\frac{1}{N} \partial_{z z}^{2} S^{(N)} d t+\frac{1}{N} \partial_{z z}^{2} S^{(N)} d t \\
& +\frac{4}{N^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\
k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle^{2}\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{j}-\lambda_{k}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(\tilde{z}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}} d t \\
& +\frac{4}{N^{2}} \sum_{\substack{i, j=1 \\
l \neq i}}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle l \mid j\rangle^{2}\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\mu_{i}-\mu_{l}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)^{2}\left(\tilde{z}-\mu_{i}\right)} d t+\frac{2}{N^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{4}}{\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)^{2}\left(\tilde{z}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}} d t
\end{aligned}
$$

Notice that, since the squared overlaps are expected to be of order $1 / N$, all terms vanish except the first three, which remain of order 1 in the scaling limit. Therefore, we are interested in combining these remaining terms to identify functions of $S^{(N)}$ and of its derivatives. First, we decompose these terms and introduce some new notations. Let us define:

- $d \Sigma_{\mu}:=\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\tilde{z}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)} d \mu_{i}$,
- $d \Sigma_{\lambda}:=\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\tilde{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)^{2}} d \lambda_{j}$.

The first term in (D.1), involving $d\left(\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}\right)$, needs to be decomposed using our previous Itô formula on the squared overlaps (3.1). It is equal to

$$
\left(I_{\lambda}+I_{\mu}+I_{\lambda \mu}\right) d t+d I_{W}+d I_{\tilde{W}}
$$

where:

- $I_{\lambda}:=\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle^{2}-\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{j}-\lambda_{k}\right)^{2}\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(\tilde{z}-\mu_{i}\right)}$ contains interactions between the $\lambda_{j}$.
- $I_{\mu}:=\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{\substack{i, j=1 \\ l \neq i}}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle l \mid j\rangle^{2}-\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\mu_{i}-\mu_{l}\right)^{2}\left(\tilde{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)}$ contains interactions between the $\mu_{i}$.

- $I_{\lambda \mu}:=\frac{2}{N^{2}} \sum_{\substack{i, l=1 \\ l \neq i}}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{\left(\langle i j j\rangle\langle l| k\right)+\langle i| k\rangle\langle l \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\mu_{i}-\mu_{l}\right)\left(\lambda_{j}-\lambda_{k}\right)\left(\hat{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)}$ contains both interactions between the $\lambda_{j}$ and between the $\mu_{i}$.

We also denoted by $d I_{W}$ and $d I_{\dot{W}}$ the terms involving the Brownian motions:

- $d I_{W}:=\frac{2}{N \sqrt{N}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{d W_{i k}\langle i| k\rangle\langle i \mid j\rangle}{\left(\lambda_{j}-\lambda_{k}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(\hat{z}-\mu_{i}\right)}$
- $d I_{\dot{W}}:=\frac{2}{N \sqrt{N}} \sum_{\substack{i, l=1 \\ l \neq i}}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{d \dot{W}_{i l}\langle l \mid j\rangle\langle i \mid j\rangle}{\left(\mu_{i}-\mu_{l}\right)\left(\hat{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)}$.

Let us now detail the steps of our computation:

1. First, we demonstrate that the terms involving the Brownian motions almost surely converge to zero as $N$ tends to infinity. This is a key step, as it explicitly shows how the randomness in $S^{(N)}$ vanishes in the scaling limit, leaving only terms that can be related to itself or to its derivatives.
2. Next, we establish that by combining $\Sigma_{\lambda}$ and $I_{\lambda}$, we can identify terms involving $\partial_{z} S^{(N)}$. Similarly, the combination of $\Sigma_{\mu}$ with $I_{\mu}$ will yield the $\partial_{\hat{z}}$ part of the equation.
3. Finally, we manipulate the term $I_{\lambda \mu}$ to show that it almost surely converges to $S^{2}$.

To manipulate the sums present in our expressions, we will use the following identity:

$$
\frac{1}{(a-b)(z-a)}-\frac{1}{(a-b)(z-b)}=\frac{1}{(z-a)(z-b)}
$$

We will also make use of two types of symmetrisations:

- $\underline{\text { Symmetrisation 1: If } a_{k l}=a_{l k}}$,

To prove this, we copy the sum $S$ into $S / 2+S / 2$, invert the indices of the second sum, and apply the identity (I).

- $\underline{\text { Symmetrisation 2: }}$

This relation is derived by expanding the sum, inverting the indices in the second term, and combining the two sums.

In this subsection, we will explicitly indicate when one of these properties is used and the concerned indices.

We recall that we are working with a fixed interval $[t, t+d t]$, and with fixed $z, \hat{z} \in \mathbb{C} \backslash \mathbb{R}$, all of which are independent of $N$.

Brownian terms. We show here that $d I_{W} \xrightarrow{\text { a.s. }} 0$ as $N$ goes to infinity. The method is identical for $d I_{\dot{W}}$. The sum $d I_{W}$ has mean zero due to the independence between $d W(t)$ and $\Phi^{t}, \Psi^{t}$, $\mu^{t}, \lambda^{t}$. We are going to use some manipulations to demonstrate that its variance is of order $\mathcal{O}\left(1 / N^{2}\right)$. Therefore, by applying Borel-Cantelli's lemma to the events $\left\{\left|d I_{W}\right|>\varepsilon\right\}$, with their probabilities bounded from above by Bienaymé-Tchebychev's inequality, we obtain almost sure convergence.

First, we apply symmetrisation (S1) to the indices $j$ and $k$, with $a_{j k}=d W_{j k}\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle i \mid j\rangle$ and $b_{j}=\lambda_{j}$. This transforms our random variable into

$$
d I_{W}=\frac{1}{N \sqrt{N}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{d W_{j k}\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle i \mid j\rangle}{\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{k}\right)\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)}
$$

This prevents having a diverging term $\frac{1}{N} \sum_{j \neq k} \frac{1}{\left(\lambda_{j}-\lambda_{k}\right)^{2}}$ in the variance, as all the eigenvalues lie in the bulk. Note that if we only account for the fact that the overlaps are of order $1 / \sqrt{N}$, this sum would be of order $\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{N})$, but since we are summing many independent variables (the $d W)$, there is a concentration of measure, and the variance will initially appear to be of order $1 / N$. The variance reads:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left|d I_{W}\right|^{2}\right]=\frac{1}{N^{3}} \sum_{i, l=1}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k, j^{\prime}, k^{\prime}=1 \\ k \neq j^{\prime} \\ k^{\prime} \neq j^{\prime}}}^{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{d W_{j k} d W_{j^{\prime} k^{\prime}}\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle l| k^{\prime}\rangle\left\langle l \mid j^{\prime}\right\rangle}{\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(z^{*}-\lambda_{j^{\prime}}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{k}\right)\left(z^{*}-\lambda_{k^{\prime}}\right)\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(\bar{z}^{*}-\mu_{l}\right)}\right]
$$

where $z^{*}$ stands for the complex conjugate of $z$. Note that $d W_{j k} d W_{j^{\prime} k^{\prime}} \neq 0$ only if $k^{\prime}=k$ and $j^{\prime}=j$ or if $k^{\prime}=j$ and $j^{\prime}=k$. In both cases $\left\langle l \mid k^{\prime}\right\rangle\left\langle l \mid j^{\prime}\right\rangle=\langle l \mid k\rangle\langle l \mid j\rangle$, thus,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left|d I_{W}\right|^{2}\right]=\frac{2}{N^{3}} \sum_{i, l=1}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle l \mid k\rangle\langle l \mid j\rangle}{\left|z-\lambda_{j}\right|^{2}\left|z-\lambda_{k}\right|^{2}\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(\bar{z}^{*}-\mu_{l}\right)}\right] d t
$$

This sum is indeed of order $1 / N$. By exploiting its specific structure, we can increase this bound to $1 / N^{2}$, ensuring almost sure convergence. Similar manipulations will be applied several times in the remainder of this paper, hence we present the method here as a general property. The key observation here is that the variance can be rewritten as

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left|d I_{W}\right|^{2}\right]=\frac{2}{N^{3}} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\left.\frac{1}{\left|z-\lambda_{j}\right|^{2}\left|z-\lambda_{k}\right|^{2}} \right\rvert\, \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle i \mid j\rangle}{\bar{z}-\mu_{i}} \right|^{2}\right] d t
$$

We now introduce the following property:

- Reduction Property:

For $z, \bar{z} \in \mathbb{C} \backslash \mathbb{R}$ and for any $p \geq 0$, we have

$$
\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{1}{\left|z-\lambda_{j}\right|^{p}\left|z-\lambda_{k}\right|^{p}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle i \mid k\rangle}{\bar{z}-\mu_{i}}\right|^{2}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{N}\right)
$$

Proof

Let us denote the sum under investigation by $\Sigma$. Using the upper bound $1 /|z-\lambda|^{2} \leq$ $1 / \Im(z)^{2}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Sigma & \leq \frac{1}{N^{2} \Im(z)^{2 p}} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\
k \neq j}}^{N}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle i \mid k\rangle}{\bar{z}-\mu_{i}}\right|^{2} \\
& \leq \frac{1}{N^{2} \Im(z)^{2 p}} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\
k \neq j}}^{N} \sum_{i, l=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle l \mid j\rangle\langle l \mid k\rangle}{\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(\bar{z}^{*}-\mu_{l}\right)} \\
& \leq \frac{1}{N^{2} \Im(z)^{2 p}} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \sum_{i, l=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle l \mid j\rangle}{\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(\bar{z}^{*}-\mu_{l}\right)} \sum_{\substack{k=1 \\
k \neq j}}^{N}\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle l \mid k\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\Psi_{1}^{t}, \ldots, \Psi_{N}^{t}$ form an orthonormal basis of $\mathbb{R}^{N}$, we recognize that

$$
\sum_{\substack{k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N}\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle l \mid k\rangle=\left\langle\Phi_{i}^{t} \mid \Phi_{l}^{t}\right\rangle-\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle l \mid j\rangle=\delta_{i l}-\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle l \mid j\rangle
$$

Therefore, our inequality becomes

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Sigma & \leq \frac{1}{N^{2} \Im(z)^{2 p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left|\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right|^{2}}-\sum_{i, l=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}\langle l \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(\bar{z}^{*}-\mu_{l}\right)}\right) \\
& \leq \frac{1}{N^{2} \Im(z)^{2 p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{\left|\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right|^{2}}-\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\bar{z}-\mu_{i}}\right|^{2}\right) \\
& \leq \frac{1}{\Im(z)^{2 p} \Im(\bar{z})^{2}} \frac{n}{N^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

by applying the same complex upper bound to the first sum. Since $n / N \rightarrow q$, we indeed have $\Sigma=\mathcal{O}(1 / N)$, which concludes our proof.

Applying (R) to (D.2) yields that the variance is of order $1 / N^{2}$.
Partial derivative terms. Our goal here is to show the following convergence:

$$
I_{\lambda} d t+d \Sigma_{\lambda} \longrightarrow-G(z, t) \partial_{z} S(z, \bar{z}, t) d t
$$

We demonstrate our method for the $\lambda$-case, and similar manipulations lead to

$$
I_{\mu} d t+d \Sigma_{\mu} \longrightarrow-q \hat{G}(\bar{z}, t) \partial_{\bar{z}} S(z, \bar{z}, t) d t
$$

We begin by manipulating $I_{\lambda}$. By applying symmetrisation (S1) to the indices $j$ and $k$, with $a_{j k}=\frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle^{2}-\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{j}-\lambda_{k}\right)}$ and $b_{j}=\lambda_{j}$, we obtain

$$
I_{\lambda}=\frac{1}{2 N^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle^{2}-\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{j}-\lambda_{k}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{k}\right)\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)}
$$

which we can split and regroup as in (S2):

$$
I_{\lambda}=\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{j}-\lambda_{k}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{k}\right)\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)}
$$

Finally, applying identity (I) with $a=\lambda_{j}$ and $b=\lambda_{k}$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{\lambda} & =\overbrace{\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\
k \neq j}}^{A_{\lambda}} \frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{j}-\lambda_{k}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{k}\right)^{2}\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)}}+\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\
k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle^{2}}{\left(z-\lambda_{k}\right)^{2}\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)} \\
& =A_{\lambda}+\left(\frac{1}{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{1}{z-\lambda_{j}}\right)\left(\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle^{2}}{\left(z-\lambda_{k}\right)^{2}\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)}-\frac{1}{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)^{2}\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)}\right) \\
& =A_{\lambda}-G_{N}(z, t) \partial_{z} S^{(N)}-\frac{1}{2 N} \partial_{z z}^{2} S^{(N)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Next, we observe that $A_{\lambda}$ can be cancelled by $d \Sigma_{\lambda}$. Indeed,

$$
d \Sigma_{\lambda}=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{N \sqrt{N}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)^{2}\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)} d B_{j}+\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\
k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{j}-\lambda_{k}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)^{2}\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)} d t
$$

(Inverting $j$ and $k$ ) $\frac{\sqrt{2}}{N \sqrt{N}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)^{2}\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)} d B_{j}-A_{\lambda} d t$,
so that

$$
I_{\lambda} d t+\Sigma_{\lambda}=-G_{N}(z, t) \partial_{z} S^{(N)} d t-\frac{1}{2 N} \partial_{z z}^{2} S^{(N)} d t+\frac{\sqrt{2}}{N \sqrt{N}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)^{2}\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)} d B_{j}
$$

where only the first term remains of order 1 in the scaling limit, while all other go to 0 . This gives the announced convergence (D.3).

Square term. Let us first expand the square in $I_{\lambda \mu}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{\lambda \mu}= & \frac{2}{N^{2}} \sum_{\substack{i, l=1 \\
l \neq i}}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\
k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}\langle l \mid k\rangle^{2}+\langle i \mid k\rangle^{2}\langle l \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\mu_{i}-\mu_{l}\right)\left(\lambda_{j}-\lambda_{k}\right)\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)} \\
& +\frac{4}{N^{2}} \sum_{\substack{i, l=1 \\
l \neq i}}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\
k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle l \mid k\rangle\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle l \mid j\rangle}{\left(\mu_{i}-\mu_{l}\right)\left(\lambda_{j}-\lambda_{k}\right)\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

We begin with the first sum. By applying symmetrisation (S1) to $(i, l)$ and then to $(j, k)$, it becomes

$$
\frac{1}{2 N^{2}} \sum_{\substack{i, l=1 \\ l \neq i}}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}\langle l \mid k\rangle^{2}+\langle i \mid k\rangle^{2}\langle l \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{l}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{k}\right)}
$$

Then, symmetrisation (S2) transforms it into

$$
\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{\substack{i, l=1 \\ l \neq i}}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}\langle l \mid k\rangle^{2}}{\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(\bar{z}-\mu_{l}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{k}\right)}
$$

We observe that if we add the diagonal terms $(l=i$ and $k=j)$, we exactly obtain $\left(S^{(N)}\right)^{2}$. One can verify that the latter all go to 0 as $N$ goes to infinity, so that this sum converges to $S^{2}$.

Finally, we address the second sum in $I_{\lambda \mu}$ and show it converges to 0 as $N \rightarrow \infty$. We first symmetrize it twice, applying (S1) to $(i, l)$ and to $(j, k)$, and obtain

$$
\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{\substack{i, l=1 \\ l \neq i}}^{n} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle l \mid k\rangle\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle l \mid j\rangle}{\left(\tilde{z}-\mu_{i}\right)\left(\tilde{z}-\mu_{l}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{k}\right)}
$$

which can be rewritten as (adding the diagonal terms $l=i$ that go to 0 in the scaling limit)

$$
\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{1}{\left(z-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(z-\lambda_{k}\right)}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle i \mid k\rangle}{\tilde{z}-\mu_{i}}\right)^{2}
$$

Thus, its modulus is bounded from above by

$$
\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{\substack{j, k=1 \\ k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{1}{\left|z-\lambda_{j}\right|\left|z-\lambda_{k}\right|}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle i \mid k\rangle}{\tilde{z}-\mu_{i}}\right|^{2}
$$

which is of order $1 / N$ using the reduction property (R). Therefore, the sum goes to 0 as $N \rightarrow \infty$.
We can now conclude by regrouping all our terms. We have proven that the limit function $S$ almost surely satisfies the equation (3.3):

$$
\partial_{t} S=-G(z, t) \partial_{z} S-q \tilde{G}(\tilde{z}, t) \partial_{\tilde{z}} S+S^{2}
$$

# D. 2 Solving the differential equation 

We solve this equation using the method of characteristics. We introduce three functions of a new variable $s: z(s), \tilde{z}(s), t(s)$. We also define $\hat{S}(s):=S(z(s), \tilde{z}(s), t(s))$. The chain rule gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d \hat{S}}{d s} & =\partial_{z} S \frac{d z}{d s}+\partial_{\tilde{z}} S \frac{d \tilde{z}}{d s}+\partial_{t} S \frac{d t}{d s} \\
& =\partial_{z} S\left(\frac{d z}{d s}-G(z(s), t(s)) \frac{d t}{d s}\right)+\partial_{\tilde{z}} S\left(\frac{d \tilde{z}}{d s}-q \tilde{G}(\tilde{z}(s), t(s)) \frac{d t}{d s}\right)+\hat{S}^{2} \frac{d t}{d s}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, if we choose our three functions such that

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{d z}{d s}=G(z(s), t(s)) \\
\frac{d \tilde{z}}{d s}=q \tilde{G}(\tilde{z}(s), t(s)) \\
\frac{d t}{d s}=1
\end{array}\right.
$$

then we will have $\frac{d \hat{S}}{d s}=\hat{S}^{2}$, i.e.

$$
\hat{S}(s)=\frac{\hat{S}(0)}{1-s \hat{S}(0)}
$$

Also, we know that $G$ satisfies $\partial_{t} G=-G \partial_{z} G$ and $\tilde{G}$ satisfies $\partial_{t} \tilde{G}=-q \tilde{G} \partial_{z} \tilde{G}$, which gives us $\frac{d^{2} z}{d s^{2}}=\frac{d^{2} \tilde{z}}{d s^{2}}=0$. Therefore, we have

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
z(s)=G(z(0), t(0)) s+z(0) \\
\tilde{z}(s)=q \tilde{G}(\tilde{z}(0), t(0)) s+\tilde{z}(0) \\
t(s)=s+t(0)
\end{array}\right.
$$

Substituting this into (D.4), evaluating for $s=-t(0)$, and noticing that $z(0), \tilde{z}(0), t(0)$ are free parameters that we can choose, we obtain the announced explicit solution (3.4):

$$
S(z, \tilde{z}, t)=\frac{S\left(z-t G(z, t), \tilde{z}-q t \tilde{G}(\tilde{z}, t), 0\right)}{1-t S\left(z-t G(z, t), \tilde{z}-q t \tilde{G}(\tilde{z}, t), 0\right)}
$$

# E Closed-form formula in the case of a pure noise matrix 

In the case $A \equiv 0$, we have (3.7):

$$
S(z, \tilde{z}, t)=\frac{q}{(z-t G(z, t))(\tilde{z}-q t \tilde{G}(\tilde{z}, t))-q t}
$$

For fixed $\lambda \in[-2 \sqrt{t}, 2 \sqrt{t}]$ and $\mu \in[-2 \sqrt{q t}, 2 \sqrt{q t}]$, we introduce

$$
\begin{aligned}
S_{ \pm} & :=\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}} S(\lambda-i \varepsilon, \mu \pm i \varepsilon, t) \\
& =\frac{q}{(\lambda-t v(\lambda, t)-i \pi t \rho(\lambda, t))(\mu-q t \tilde{v}(\mu, t) \pm i q \pi t \tilde{\rho}(\mu, t))-q t}
\end{aligned}
$$

so that by using (3.5),

$$
W(\mu, \lambda, t)=\frac{1}{2 \pi^{2} q \rho(\lambda, t) \tilde{\rho}(\mu, t)} \Re\left(S_{+}-S_{-}\right)
$$

We use the following notations:

- $V:=\lambda-t v(\lambda, t)$. Knowing that $v(\lambda, t)=\lambda / 2 t$, we have $V=\lambda / 2$.
- $R:=\pi t \rho(\lambda, t)$.
- $\tilde{V}:=\mu-q t \tilde{v}(\mu, t)=\mu / 2$.
- $\tilde{R}:=q \pi t \tilde{\rho}(\mu, t)$.

We begin by simplifying

$$
\begin{aligned}
S_{ \pm} & =\frac{q}{(V-i R)(\tilde{V} \pm i \tilde{R})-q t} \\
& =\frac{q}{V \tilde{V} \pm R \tilde{R}-q t-i(R \tilde{V} \mp \tilde{R} V)} \\
& =q \frac{V \tilde{V} \pm R \tilde{R}-q t+i(R \tilde{V} \mp \tilde{R} V)}{(V \tilde{V} \pm R \tilde{R}-q t)^{2}+(R \tilde{V} \mp \tilde{R} V)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

This allows us to identify its real part. Our goal is to obtain a simplified form of

$$
\Re\left(S_{+}-S_{-}\right)=q \frac{V \tilde{V}+R \tilde{R}-q t}{(V \tilde{V}+R \tilde{R}-q t)^{2}+(R \tilde{V}-\tilde{R} V)^{2}}-q \frac{V \tilde{V}-R \tilde{R}-q t}{(V \tilde{V}-R \tilde{R}-q t)^{2}+(R \tilde{V}+\tilde{R} V)^{2}}
$$

We denote it as $\Re\left(S_{+}-S_{-}\right)=N_{+} / D_{+}-N_{-} / D_{-}$. We combine the two fractions under the product of the denominators and start by factorizing the numerator:

$$
\begin{aligned}
N_{+} D_{-}-N_{-} D_{+} & =q\left(V \tilde{V}+R \tilde{R}-q t\right)\left((V \tilde{V}-R \tilde{R}-q t)^{2}+(R \tilde{V}+\tilde{R} V)^{2}\right) \\
& -q\left(V \tilde{V}-R \tilde{R}-q t\right)\left((V \tilde{V}+R \tilde{R}-q t)^{2}+(R \tilde{V}-\tilde{R} V)^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the identities $(x+y)^{2}-(x-y)^{2}=4 x y$ and $(x+y)^{2}+(x-y)^{2}=2 x^{2}+2 y^{2}$, we transform it into

$$
\begin{aligned}
N_{+} D_{-}-N_{-} D_{+} & =4 q(V \tilde{V}-q t)\left(-(V \tilde{V}-q t) R \tilde{R}+V \tilde{V} R \tilde{R}\right) \\
& +2 q R \tilde{R}\left((V \tilde{V}-q t)^{2}+R^{2} \tilde{R}^{2}+R^{2} \tilde{V}^{2}+\tilde{R}^{2} V^{2}\right) \\
& =2 q R \tilde{R}\left(V^{2} \tilde{V}^{2}+R^{2} \tilde{R}^{2}+R^{2} \tilde{V}^{2}+\tilde{R}^{2} V^{2}-q^{2} t^{2}\right) \\
& =2 q R \tilde{R}\left[\left(V^{2}+R^{2}\right)\left(\tilde{V}^{2}+\tilde{R}^{2}\right)-q^{2} t^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Now we recall that

$$
R^{2}=\pi^{2} t^{2} \frac{4 t-\lambda^{2}}{4 \pi^{2} t^{2}}=t-\frac{\lambda^{2}}{4}
$$

so that $V^{2}+R^{2}=t$. Similarly, $\tilde{V}^{2}+\tilde{R}^{2}=q t$. Finally, our numerator equals $2 q^{2}(1-q) t^{2} R \tilde{R}$.
We finish by simplifying the denominator, which is the product of the two initial denominators. First, the denominators of each fraction are

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{ \pm} & =(V \tilde{V}-q t \pm R \tilde{R})^{2}+(R \tilde{V} \mp \tilde{R} V)^{2} \\
& =\left(V^{2}+R^{2}\right)\left(\tilde{V}^{2}+\tilde{R}^{2}\right)+q^{2} t^{2}-2 q t V \tilde{V} \mp 2 q t R \tilde{R} \\
& =q t((1+q) t-2 V \tilde{V} \mp 2 R \tilde{R})
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, using $(x+y)(x-y)=x^{2}-y^{2}$, the product of the two denominators becomes

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{+} D_{-} & =q^{2} t^{2}\left(((1+q) t-2 V \tilde{V})^{2}-4 R^{2} \tilde{R}^{2}\right) \\
& =q^{2} t^{2}\left(4 V^{2} \tilde{V}^{2}-4 R^{2} \tilde{R}^{2}-4(1+q) t V \tilde{V}+t^{2}\right) \\
& =q^{2} t^{2}\left(\frac{\lambda^{2} \mu^{2}}{4}-4\left(t-\frac{\lambda^{2}}{4}\right)\left(q t-\frac{\mu^{2}}{4}\right)-(1+q) t \lambda \mu+(1+q)^{2} t^{2}\right) \\
& =q^{2} t^{2}\left(t \mu^{2}+q t \lambda^{2}-(1+q) t \lambda \mu-4 q t^{2}+(1+q)^{2} t^{2}\right) \\
& =q^{2} t^{3}\left((\mu-\lambda)(\mu-q \lambda)+(1-q)^{2} t\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

so that finally,

$$
\Re\left(S_{+}-S_{-}\right)=\frac{2 q^{2}(1-q) t^{2} R \tilde{R}}{q^{2} t^{3}\left((\mu-\lambda)(\mu-q \lambda)+(1-q)^{2} t\right)}=\frac{2 \pi^{2} q(1-q) t \rho(\lambda, t) \tilde{\rho}(\mu, t)}{(1-q)^{2} t+(\mu-\lambda)(\mu-q \lambda)}
$$

and we obtain the announced formula (3.8):

$$
W(\mu, \lambda, t)=\frac{(1-q) t}{(1-q)^{2} t+(\mu-\lambda)(\mu-q \lambda)}
$$

# F Study of the cubic equation 

We define the polynomial $P(X):=q X^{3}-\left(\left(1+6 q+q^{2}\right) t+\mu^{2}\right) X+4(1+q) t \mu$. One can first check that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& P(2 \sqrt{t})=-2 \sqrt{t}((1+q) \sqrt{t}-\mu)^{2}<0 \\
& P(-2 \sqrt{t})=2 \sqrt{t}((1+q) \sqrt{t}+\mu)^{2}>0
\end{aligned}
$$

These inequalities can only become large in extreme cases like $q=1$ or $t=0$, because we always have $-2 \sqrt{q t} \leq \mu \leq 2 \sqrt{q t}$. Since $\lim _{x \rightarrow \pm \infty} P(x)= \pm \infty$, we conclude that $P$ has three real roots: one in $]-\infty,-2 \sqrt{t}[$, one in $[-2 \sqrt{t}, 2 \sqrt{t}]$, and one in $] 2 \sqrt{t},+\infty[$. Therefore, our maximisation problem always has a unique solution $\lambda_{*} \in[-2 \sqrt{t}, 2 \sqrt{t}]$.

Recalling that $\mu=\mu(x, t)$, we want to prove that

$$
\lambda(q x+1-q, t) \leq \lambda_{*} \leq \lambda(q x, t)
$$

In order to do so, we first demonstrate some properties of the quantile functions $\lambda(\cdot, t)$ and $\mu(\cdot, t)$ :

- Since $\rho(\cdot, t)$ is even, one can easily check that $\lambda(1-x, t)=-\lambda(x, t)$.

- We have the scaling inequality $\sqrt{q} \lambda(x, t) \leq \lambda(q x, t)$ for $q \in[0,1]$. This comes from comparing the integrals that define the quantile function (see (2.12)):

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\lambda(q x, t)}^{+\infty} \rho(\lambda, t) d \lambda & =q x \\
& =q \int_{\lambda(x, t)}^{+\infty} \frac{\sqrt{4 t-\lambda^{2}}}{2 \pi t} d \lambda \\
& =\sqrt{q} \int_{\sqrt{q} \lambda(x, t)}^{+\infty} \frac{\sqrt{4 t-\lambda^{2} / q}}{2 \pi t} d \lambda \\
& =\int_{\sqrt{q} \lambda(x, t)}^{+\infty} \frac{\sqrt{4 q t-\lambda^{2}}}{2 \pi t} d \lambda \\
& \leq \int_{\sqrt{q} \lambda(x, t)}^{+\infty} \frac{\sqrt{4 t-\lambda^{2}}}{2 \pi t} d \lambda
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the integrand is the same in the initial and final integrals and is positive, we deduce that $\sqrt{q} \lambda(x, t) \leq \lambda(q x, t)$.

- We have the relation $\mu(x, t)=\sqrt{q} \lambda(x, t)$ between the quantile functions associated with $\tilde{\rho}$ and with $\rho$. Once again, we use their definitions:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\mu(x, t)}^{+\infty} \frac{\sqrt{4 q t-\mu^{2}}}{2 q \pi t} d \mu & =x \\
& =\int_{\lambda(x, t)}^{+\infty} \frac{\sqrt{4 t-\lambda^{2}}}{2 \pi t} d \lambda \\
& =\int_{\sqrt{q} \lambda(x, t)}^{+\infty} \frac{\sqrt{4 t-\lambda^{2} / q}}{2 \sqrt{q} \pi t} d \lambda \\
& =\int_{\sqrt{q} \lambda(x, t)}^{+\infty} \frac{\sqrt{4 q t-\lambda^{2}}}{2 q \pi t} d \lambda
\end{aligned}
$$

The integrands in the initial integral is the same as in the final one. Additionally, since we work inside the support of $\tilde{\rho}$, the integrand is strictly positive. Therefore, the integration bounds must be identical, i.e. $\mu(x, t)=\sqrt{q} \lambda(x, t)$.
We now consider the case $x \geq 1 / 2$, meaning that $\mu \geq 0$ and $\lambda(x, t) \geq 0$. The case $x<1 / 2$ is symmetric. Combining the first two properties allows us to obtain

$$
\lambda(q x+1-q, t)=\lambda(1-q(1-x), t)=-\lambda(q(1-x), t) \leq-\sqrt{q} \lambda(1-x, t)=\sqrt{q} \lambda(x, t)
$$

Since $\lambda(x, t) \geq 0$ and $\lambda(\cdot, t)$ is non-increasing,

$$
\lambda(q x+1-q, t) \leq \sqrt{q} \lambda(x, t) \leq \lambda(x, t) \leq \lambda(q x, t)
$$

or, using our third property,

$$
\lambda(q x+1-q, t) \leq \mu \leq \frac{\mu}{\sqrt{q}} \leq \lambda(q x, t)
$$

Finally, one can check that

$$
P(\mu)=(1-q) \mu\left((3+q) t-\mu^{2}\right) \geq 3(1-q)^{2} \mu t \geq 0
$$

using the fact that $\mu^{2} \leq 4 q t$, and that

$$
P\left(\frac{\mu}{\sqrt{q}}\right)=-\frac{\mu t}{\sqrt{q}}(1-\sqrt{q})^{4} \leq 0
$$

Since both $\mu$ and $\mu / \sqrt{q}$ lie in $[-2 \sqrt{t}, 2 \sqrt{t}]$, we must have $\mu \leq \lambda_{*} \leq \mu / \sqrt{q}$, i.e.

$$
\lambda(q x+1-q, t) \leq \lambda_{*} \leq \lambda(q x, t)
$$

# G Spike-spike overlap equation 

For this proof, we will need a spike variant of the reduction property (R), using the fact that $\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)$ is not complex but converges to $\lambda_{1}(t)$, which is distinct from the limiting bulk of radius $2 \sqrt{t}:$

- Reduction property for the spike case:

For any $z \in \mathbb{C} \backslash \mathbb{R}$ and for any $p \geq 0$,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{1}{N} \sum_{k>1}^{N} \frac{1}{\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right|^{p}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle i \mid 1\rangle}{z-\mu_{i}}\right|^{2}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right) \\
\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{\substack{j, k>1 \\
k \neq j}}^{N} \frac{1}{\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{j}\right|^{p}\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right|^{p}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle i \mid k\rangle}{z-\mu_{i}}\right|^{2}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Proof
We prove the first equation (R'). Let $\Sigma_{p}$ be the sum under investigation. For any $p \geq 0$, $\Sigma_{p}$ is of order 1 , as the denominator $\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right|$ does not diverge in the scaling limit since $\lambda_{1}(t)$ is a spike.
Next, we note the following inequality:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right|^{p}}-\frac{1}{\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right|^{p}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}} & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right|^{p}\left(\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right|^{p}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)} \\
& \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{N}\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right|^{2 p}}
\end{aligned}
$$

so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Sigma_{p} & \leq \frac{1}{N} \sum_{k>1}^{N} \frac{1}{\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right|^{p}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle i \mid 1\rangle}{z-\mu_{i}}\right|^{2}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \Sigma_{2 p} \\
& \leq \frac{1}{N} \sum_{k>1}^{N} \frac{1}{\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right|^{p}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle i \mid 1\rangle}{z-\mu_{i}}\right|^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The idea here is to approximate $\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)$ by $\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)+i \varepsilon_{N}$, where $\varepsilon_{N}$ tends to zero at an optimal speed. Therefore, we can apply an upper bound similar to the one used in (R). Since $\frac{1}{\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{j}\right|^{p}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}}$ is bounded from above by $\sqrt{N}$, we proceed similarly to the proof of (R). Denoting by $\widetilde{\Sigma}_{p}$ the sum

$$
\frac{1}{N} \sum_{k>1}^{N} \frac{1}{\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right|^{p}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle i \mid 1\rangle}{z-\mu_{i}}\right|^{2}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widehat{\Sigma}_{p} & \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \sum_{k>1}^{N}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle i \mid 1\rangle}{z-\mu_{i}}\right|^{2} \\
& \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \sum_{i, l=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid 1\rangle\langle l \mid 1\rangle}{\left(z-\mu_{i}\right)\left(z^{*}-\mu_{l}\right)} \sum_{k>1}^{N}\langle i \mid k\rangle\langle l \mid k\rangle \\
& \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \sum_{i, l=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid 1\rangle\langle l \mid 1\rangle}{\left(z-\mu_{i}\right)\left(z^{*}-\mu_{l}\right)}\left(\delta_{i l}-\langle i \mid 1\rangle\langle l \mid 1\rangle\right) \\
& \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid 1\rangle^{2}}{\left|z-\mu_{i}\right|^{2}}-\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid 1\rangle}{z-\mu_{i}}\right|^{2}\right) \\
& \leq \frac{1}{\Im(z)^{2} \sqrt{N}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, we conclude with:

$$
\Sigma_{p}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)
$$

One can verify that this is the best rate of convergence possible using this method. Specifically, using $\left(\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{j}\right|^{p}+N^{-\alpha}\right)^{-1}$ results in a order of $\mathcal{O}\left(N^{-\alpha}+N^{\alpha-1}\right)$, which is optimal for $\alpha=1 / 2$.
Finally, property (R") is easily proved using the same method, by comparing $\left(\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\right.\right.$ $\left.\lambda_{j}\right|^{p}\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right|^{p}$ ) $^{-1}$ and $\left(\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{j}\right|^{p}\left|\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right|^{p}+N^{-1 / 2}\right)^{-1}$.

We first note that property (R") allows us to extend the results from Appendix D to the spike case. Specifically,

$$
\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j>1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(z-\mu_{i}\right)} \rightarrow S\left(\lambda_{1}(t), z, t\right)=\frac{q}{\left(\lambda_{1}(t)-t G\left(\lambda_{1}(t), t\right)\right)(z-q t \widetilde{G}(z, t))-q t}
$$

Indeed, (R") adapts the original property (R), which was the only point for which we used the fact that $z \notin \mathbb{R}$ in the demonstration from Appendix D (one would get an order $1 / N^{3 / 2}$ variance for $d I_{W}$ instead of $1 / N^{2}$, but this is still summable so the almost sure convergence holds). One can also verify that (R') and (R") hold with $z \leftarrow \mu_{1}^{N}(t)$, which is the form we will use in this computation.

Using our Itô formula (3.1) for the squared overlaps, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
d\left(\langle 1 \mid 1\rangle^{2}\right)= & \frac{1}{N} \sum_{k>1}^{N} \frac{\langle 1 \mid k\rangle^{2}-\langle 1 \mid 1\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right)^{2}} d t+\frac{1}{N} \sum_{l>1}^{n} \frac{\langle l \mid 1\rangle^{2}-\langle 1 \mid 1\rangle^{2}}{\left(\mu_{1}^{N}(t)-\mu_{l}\right)^{2}} d t \\
& +\frac{2}{N} \sum_{l>1}^{n} \sum_{k>1}^{N} \frac{\langle 1 \mid 1\rangle^{2}\langle l \mid k\rangle^{2}+\langle 1 \mid k\rangle^{2}\langle l \mid 1\rangle^{2}+2\langle 1 \mid 1\rangle\langle l \mid k\rangle\langle 1 \mid k\rangle\langle l \mid 1\rangle}{\left(\mu_{1}^{N}(t)-\mu_{l}\right)\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right)} d t \\
& +\frac{2}{\sqrt{N}} \sum_{k>1}^{N} \frac{d W_{1 k}}{\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}}\langle 1 \mid k\rangle\langle 1 \mid 1\rangle+\frac{2}{\sqrt{N}} \sum_{l>1}^{n} \frac{d \tilde{W}_{1 l}}{\mu_{1}^{N}(t)-\mu_{l}}\langle l \mid 1\rangle\langle 1 \mid 1\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

We will demonstrate that this equation converges to (4.1) without any rescaling, provided that all the overlaps involving an eigenvector in the bulk are of order $1 / N$ (which makes sense considering the normalization constraints). This would confirm that $\langle 1 \mid 1\rangle^{2}$ remains of order 1 in the scaling limit. We begin by recognizing the following convergences:

- $\frac{1}{N} \sum_{k>1}^{N} \frac{\langle 1 \mid 1\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right)^{2}} \longrightarrow \int_{\mathbb{R}} \frac{\rho(\lambda, t)}{\left(\lambda_{1}(t)-\lambda\right)^{2}} d \lambda f(t)$, where $\rho$ is the semicircular density of radius $2 \sqrt{t}$, corresponding to the limiting density of all the $\lambda_{k}$ with $k \neq 1$.
- $\frac{1}{N} \sum_{l>1}^{n} \frac{\langle 1 \mid 1\rangle^{2}}{\left(\mu_{1}^{N}(t)-\mu_{l}\right)^{2}} \longrightarrow \int_{\mathbb{R}} \frac{\tilde{\rho}(\mu, t)}{\left(\mu_{1}(t)-\mu\right)^{2}} d \mu f(t)$.
- $\frac{1}{N} \sum_{l>1}^{n} \sum_{k>1}^{N} \frac{\langle 1 \mid 1\rangle^{2}\langle l \mid k\rangle^{2}}{\left(\mu_{1}^{N}(t)-\mu\right)\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right)} \longrightarrow S\left(\lambda_{1}(t), \mu_{1}(t), t\right) f(t)$, from what we just proved.

All the other $d t$-terms vanish in the scaling limit. The sum

$$
\sum_{k>1}^{N} \frac{\langle 1 \mid k\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right)^{2}}
$$

remains of order 1 as $N$ increases because $\langle 1 \mid k\rangle^{2}$ is of order $1 / N$ and $\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)$ is asymptotically distinct from the bulk for $t<\lambda^{2}$. Since it is multiplied by $1 / N$ in (G.1), it converges to 0 . The same reasoning applies to

$$
\frac{1}{N} \sum_{l>1}^{n} \frac{\langle l \mid 1\rangle^{2}}{\left(\mu_{1}^{N}(t)-\mu_{l}\right)^{2}}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{N}\right)
$$

and to

$$
\frac{4}{N} \sum_{l>1}^{n} \sum_{k>1}^{N} \frac{\langle l \mid k\rangle\langle 1 \mid k\rangle\langle l \mid 1\rangle}{\left(\mu_{1}^{N}(t)-\mu_{l}\right)\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right)}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)
$$

The argument is similar for the Brownian terms, but we must analyse their variances. Since they are centered, the variance of the first Brownian sum is

$$
\frac{4}{N} \sum_{k, k^{\prime}>1}^{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{d W_{1 k} d W_{1 k^{\prime}}\langle 1 \mid k\rangle\left\langle 1 \mid k^{\prime}\right\rangle\langle 1 \mid 1\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right)\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k^{\prime}}\right)}\right]=\frac{4}{N} \sum_{k>1}^{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{\langle 1 \mid k\rangle^{2}\langle 1 \mid 1\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right)^{2}}\right] d t=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{N}\right)
$$

where we only used the fact that $\langle 1 \mid k\rangle^{2}$ is of order $1 / N$ and $\langle 1 \mid 1\rangle^{2}$ is bounded from above by 1 . Therefore, the sum converges to 0 in $L^{2}$, and the same argument applies to the second Brownian sum.

Finally, the only terms that remain give us the deterministic limiting equation (4.1):

$$
f^{\prime}(t)=\left[-\int_{\mathbb{R}} \frac{\rho(\lambda, t)}{\left(\lambda_{1}(t)-\lambda\right)^{2}} d \lambda-q \int_{\mathbb{R}} \frac{\tilde{\rho}(\mu, t)}{\left(\mu_{1}(t)-\mu\right)^{2}} d \mu+2 S\left(\lambda_{1}(t), \mu_{1}(t), t\right)\right] f(t)
$$

Note that all these convergences are justified by the fact that $\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)$ and $\mu_{1}^{N}(t)$ asymptotically become the spikes $\lambda_{1}(t)$ and $\mu_{1}(t)$, which are distinct from their respective bulks. Therefore, the term $1 / N \sum_{k} 1 /\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{k}\right)^{2}$ does not diverge in the scaling limit (similarly for $\mu_{1}^{N}(t)$ ).

# H Spike-bulk Stieltjes transform equation 

With what we proved in Appendix G, we also have the convergence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{N} \sum_{\substack{i=1 \\
j>1}}^{n, N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{j}\right)^{2}\left(z-\mu_{i}\right)} & \longrightarrow-\partial_{1} S\left(\lambda_{1}(t), z, t\right) \\
& =\frac{q\left(1-t \partial_{1} G\left(\lambda_{1}(t), t\right)\right)(z-q t \tilde{G}(z, t))}{\left(\left(\lambda_{1}(t)-t G\left(\lambda_{1}(t), t\right)\right)(z-q t \tilde{G}(z, t))-q t\right)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the simplifications derived in 4.1, we obtain

$$
\frac{1}{N} \sum_{\substack{i=1 \\ j>1}}^{n, N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(z-\mu_{i}\right)} \longrightarrow \frac{q}{\lambda(z-q t \tilde{G}(z, t))-q t}
$$

and

$$
\frac{1}{N} \sum_{\substack{i=1 \\ j>1}}^{n, N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{j}\right)^{2}\left(z-\mu_{i}\right)} \longrightarrow \frac{q \lambda^{2}(z-q t \tilde{G}(z, t))}{\left(\lambda^{2}-t\right)\left(\lambda(z-q t \tilde{G}(z, t))-q t\right)^{2}}
$$

Now, we apply Itô's lemma to $S_{\lambda}^{(n)}$, without explicitly writing the terms that vanish as $N$ goes to infinity (see Appendix D. 1 for a detailed treatment of these terms):

$$
d S_{\lambda}^{(n)}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{d\left(\langle i \mid 1\rangle^{2}\right)}{z-\mu_{i}}+\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid 1\rangle^{2}}{\left(z-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}} d \mu_{i}+o(1)
$$

Let us decompose the first sum using the Itô formula (3.1),

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{d\left(\langle i \mid 1\rangle^{2}\right)}{z-\mu_{i}}=\left(I_{\mu}^{\prime}+I_{\lambda}^{\prime}+I_{\lambda \mu}^{\prime}\right) d t+d I_{W}^{\prime}+d I_{W}^{\prime}
$$

where:

- $I_{\mu}^{\prime}=\frac{1}{N} \sum_{\substack{i, j=1 \\ j \neq i}}^{n} \frac{\langle i \mid 1\rangle^{2}-\langle i \mid 1\rangle^{2}}{\left(\mu_{i}-\mu_{j}\right)^{2}\left(z-\mu_{i}\right)}$,
- $I_{\lambda}^{\prime}=\frac{1}{N} \sum_{\substack{i=1 \\ j>1}}^{n, N} \frac{\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}-\langle i \mid 1\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{i}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{j}\right)^{2}\left(z-\mu_{i}\right)}$,
- $I_{\lambda \mu}^{\prime}=\frac{2}{N} \sum_{\substack{i, j=1 \\ s \neq i}}^{n} \sum_{j>1}^{N} \frac{\langle i \mid 1\rangle^{2}\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}+\langle i \mid j\rangle^{2}\langle i \mid 1\rangle^{2}+2\langle i \mid 1\rangle\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle i \mid 1\rangle}{\left(\mu_{i}-\mu_{j}\right)\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(z-\mu_{i}\right)}$,
- $d I_{W}^{\prime}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{N}} \sum_{\substack{i=1 \\ j>1}}^{n, N} \frac{d W_{i j}\langle i \mid j\rangle\langle i \mid 1\rangle}{\left(\lambda_{1}^{N}(t)-\lambda_{j}\right)\left(z-\mu_{i}\right)}$,
- $d I_{W}^{\prime}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{N}} \sum_{\substack{i, j=1 \\ j \neq i}}^{n} \frac{d W_{i i}\langle i \mid 1\rangle\langle i \mid 1\rangle}{\left(\mu_{i}-\mu_{j}\right)\left(z-\mu_{i}\right)}$.

We explicit the limit of each of these terms in order to explain how equation (4.4) arises. The manipulations are very similar to those in Appendix D.1:

1. $I_{\mu}^{\prime} d t$ combined with the second sum in (H.3) converges to $-q \tilde{G}(z, t) \partial_{z} S_{\lambda} d t$.
2. $I_{\lambda}^{\prime}$ converges to $\frac{q \lambda^{2}(z-q t \tilde{G}(z, t))}{\left(\lambda^{2}-t\right)\left(\lambda(z-q t \tilde{G}(z, t)-q t\right)^{2}}-\int \frac{p(\lambda, t)}{\left(\lambda_{1}(t)-\lambda\right)^{2}} d \lambda S_{\lambda}(z, t)$, using (H.2). The integral simplifies to $1 /\left(\lambda^{2}-t\right)$.
3. $I_{\lambda \mu}^{\prime}$ converges to $\frac{2 q}{\lambda(z-q t \tilde{G}(z, t))-q t} S_{\lambda}(z, t)$, using the $(i, s)$ symmetry and equation (H.1), as well as property ( $\mathrm{R}^{\prime}$ ) which shows that when we expand the sum in three terms, the third one vanishes.

4. $d I_{W}^{\prime}$ converges to 0 in the scaling limit using ( $\mathrm{R}^{\prime}$ ). This time the variance can be shown to be of order $1 / \sqrt{N}$, so almost sure convergence is not guaranteed.
5. $d I_{W}^{\prime}$ also converges to 0 . This can be shown using the same method we applied to $d I_{W}$ and $d I_{\hat{W}}$ in Appendix D.1.

Combining all these terms gives us equation (4.4):

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial_{t} S_{\lambda}= & -q \hat{G}(z, t) \partial_{z} S_{\lambda}+\left(\frac{2 q}{\lambda(z-q t \hat{G}(z, t))-q t}+\frac{1}{t-\lambda^{2}}\right) S_{\lambda} \\
& +\frac{q \lambda^{2}(z-q t \hat{G}(z, t))}{\left(\lambda^{2}-t\right)\left(\lambda(z-q t \hat{G}(z, t))-q t\right)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

abstract:
We consider the eigenvectors of the principal minor of dimension $n< N$ of
the Dyson Brownian motion in $\mathbb{R}^{N}$ and investigate their asymptotic
overlaps with the eigenvectors of the full matrix in the limit of large
dimension. We explicitly compute the limiting rescaled mean squared overlaps in
the large $n\,, N$ limit with $n\,/\,N$ tending to a fixed ratio $q\,$, for any
initial symmetric matrix $A\,$. This is accomplished using a Burgers-type
evolution equation for a specific resolvent. In the GOE case, our formula
simplifies, and we identify an eigenvector analogue of the well-known
interlacing of eigenvalues. We investigate in particular the case where $A$ has
isolated eigenvalues. Our method is based on analysing the eigenvector flow
under the Dyson Brownian motion.
